name: "Chinese" Garage
description: A Grade II listed motor garage and petrol station built in the style of a Japanese pagoda in 1928. Now a Tesco Express.
address: Chinese Garage, Stone Park Avenue, BR3 3FE

name: 'Maiden Voyage' by JeeYoung Lee
description: For NOW Gallery’s 2022 Art Commission JeeYoung Lee has created an environment inspired by memories, dreams, emotions, and her personal experience. The artist reinterprets her psychological landscape and thoughts into this environment.

name: 1 Finsbury Avenue
description: 1 Finsbury Avenue is a Grade II listed building constructed in the early 1980s by Arup Associates (Peter Foggo). As the first building in the Broadgate development it was significant in defining the speculative office typology in London.

name: 1 Halsbury Close
description: Grade II Modernist House designed by German emigre architect Rudolf Frankel for his sister and family in 1938. The house remains relatively intact and retains the layout and original features which adhere to Modernist principles of the era.

name: 17a–79b Mansfield Road (access to two flats)
description: The long terrace at 17a–79b Mansfield Road was the last part of the post-war Gospel Oak Redevelopment Area to be completed, and formed part of the London Borough of Camden’s ‘Golden Era’ of housing under borough architect Sydney Cook.

name: 186A Uxbridge Road
description:
Semi-detached residential 2-bed house totally refurbished by the owner-architect.
The main works included demolition of str. walls to achieve open plan living, new bathrooms, kitchen, porch, windows, green roof, UFH and insulation.

name: 264 Westbourne Park Road
description: New building as an urban accent - two independent houses atop each other. Contemporary in design it draws from the tectonic composition of adjacent Victorian houses. Features include rain water harvesting,  roof garden, solar water heating.

name: 3D Printing at Design District
description: We are opening the doors of our 3D Printing Studio at the Design District for all to experience the wonders of 3D printing. Come learn about this innovative technology, touch the materials, and see 3D printers in action!
address: 10 Monro Way, Unit 1.1, Building A4, Greenwich

name: A Ruskinian Walk Through Shared Heritage
description: Ruskinian walk from RIBA award-winning Chiswick Business Park, Gunnersbury Triangle Nature Reserve through South Acton Estate, birthplace of artist Patrick Caulfield; Woodlands Park Ice House; to home of Wm Willett, of Daylight Saving Time

name: A walk through the 'Great White City'
description: A walk though White City exploring how its built environment has transformed multiple times in the past century and discussing what developers have emphasized and downplayed about the area's heritage to attract people to the area.
address: In front of Japan Centre Ichiba Supermarket Uni

name: Altab Ali Park
description: Altab Ali Park was renamed in 1998 after a murdered 25-year-old Bangladeshi Sylheti clothing worker. Formerly known as St. Mary's Park, it is the site of the old 14 C white church, St. Mary Matfelon which gave Whitechapel its name.

name: Argentine Ambassador's Residence
description:
"ARGENTINA AT THE LONDON DESIGN FESTIVAL 2022" 
During Open House Festival people will have the unique opportunity to visit and explore the historic mansion host to the exhibition “Creative experience- From Argentina to the world”

name: Art in Perpetuity Trust
description: Open Studios, provides a unique glimpse to the architectural spaces and working studios of APT artists.  Over the weekend, there is also the opportunity to see our Group Show in the Gallery, curated by and featuring APT artist's work.

name: BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir
description: Europe’s first traditional Hindu temple is a masterpiece of exquisite Indian craftsmanship. Using 5,000 tonnes of Italian and Indian marble and the finest Bulgarian limestone, it was hand-carved in India before being assembled in London.

name: Barbican Centre
description: The Barbican Centre is a world-class arts, learning and conference centre set in the Grade II listed Barbican Estate – one of London’s best examples of Brutalist architecture.

name: Benjamin Franklin House
description: Grade I listed Georgian house, the only surviving home of Benjamin Franklin, retaining many original features including central staircase, lathing, 18th Century panelling, stoves, windows, fittings and beams.

name: Blackbook Winery
description: Blackbook Winery is in a converted Victorian railway arch.  It is open plan, with all equipment required to process, ferment and age wine on site – press, tanks, barrels etc.  Our grapes come from English growers within 2 hours of London.

name: Blenheim Gardens Estate
description: Blenheim Gardens Estate was designed and built in the late 1960s - early 1970s by Lambeth’s Architecture Department under Ted Hollamby. It marks the shift from system-built high-rise towards communal and pedestrian-dominated spaces.

name: Bluebell Centre, Perivale Wood Nature Reserve
description: The low carbon building is a straw bale construction built on compacted tyres with a cedar roof.  In the Perivale Nature Reserve owned by the Selborne Society it is used for society meeting and as an education centre for adults and schools.

name: Brentford Canal Toll House and Gauging Lock
description: Single-storey canal toll house (1911) where tolls were collected for passing through the lock. Grand Junction Canal connected the Thames at Brentford to the Industrial Midlands in 1794 at the height of the industrial revolution.
address: Access off High Street, Brentford, TW8 8EE

name: Bruce Castle Museum
description: Tudor Manor House built for Sir William Compton in 1514, substantially altered in 17C, 18C & 19C. A museum since 1906 housing local history and community collections, archives, art & exhibitions of Bruce Castle, and Haringey area.
address: Bruce Castle Museum,, Lordship Lane, Tottenham

name: C1
description: An open and welcoming building, intent on fostering community. A rooftop basketball court crowns three storeys of studio space, all accessible via open-air staircases doubling as communal spaces.
address: C1, The Gateway Pavilions, Design District

name: C3 - Bureau
description: C3 is home to Bureau, a members club at the heart of Design District. Its undulating white facade creates informal pockets of space on the interior, ideal for flexible working models.

name: CUFOS - Community Use For the Old Station
description: The former Alexandra Palace Railway Station now run by a charity for use by local people and organisations for classes, meetings and many other leisure activities.
address: CUFOS, Top of The Avenue, Muswell Hill, N10 2QE

name: Camden Place (Chislehurst Golf Club)
description: Grade ll* early 18C mansion.  Unique panelled dining room from the Chateau de Bercy, 18C Dutch wall paintings and  exquisite original plaster ceiling and Grade ll Temple shaped folly  by James 'Athenian' Stuart. .  Golf Club from 1894.ple s
address: Camden Place, Camden Park Road, Chislehurst

name: Canal club community centre reopening party
description:
Learn about architect Julian Sofaer and join in with activities related to our community garden.

Draw local endangered flowers: 
Sunday 3pm - 4pm

Learn about fruit & veg grown locally: 
Saturday 2.30pm - 4pm 
Sunday 1pm - 2.30pm
address: Canal club community centre, Waterloo gardens

name: Cannizaro Studios
description:
Victorian Potting sheds converted to artists' studios set within the grounds of Grade II listed Cannizaro Park.
The eight resident artists will be displaying their work during the festival at these unique studios.
address: The old Potting sheds, Cannizaro Park, SW19 4UW

name: Carshalton Water Tower and Historic Gardens
description: Early 18C Grade II listed building incorporating plunge bath with Delft tiles, orangery, saloon and pump chamber with part-restored water wheel. Hermitage and sham bridge in grounds.

name: Central Hill Estate
description: Tree-lined housing estate on the ridge of Central Hill & Crystal Palace, incorporating open spaces, views over London, gardens and sense of community. Rosemary Stjernstedt Ted Hollamby Adrian Sansom, Lambeth Borough Architects 1963.
address: Central Hill Bowl (behind Gipsy Hill Police Sta

name: Christ Church, Streatham
description: Grade I listed pioneering brick polychromy. Designed with early Christian, Italian, Ottoman, Alhambran, Mamluk, Sevillean and Ancient Egyptian influences with fine mosaics and stained glass by Crane, Bentley. Lee and Hayward.

name: Church of St Mary the Blessed Virgin
description: Founded in 11C, with Jacobean memorial c1615. Burial site of 5 Archbishops of Canterbury.

name: Clapham Old Town and Venn Street
description: This guided walk around Clapham's Old Town features a radically redesigned public realm which changed the emphasis of the street environment to encourage people to walk and cycle instead of driving.

name: Cody Dock
description: One of London's most exciting creative spaces, Cody Dock provides a gateway to the Lea River Park and is home to a gallery, gardens, cafe & bar that make this the perfect pit stop for exploring The Line Sculpture trail and Lower Lea River.

name: Copper Coffee House
description: The Copper Coffee House is a combination of neo-futuristic form and innovative use of copper that results in a functioning café that acts a work of public sculpture.

name: Cromwell Place
description: A first of its kind global arts destination, Cromwell Place is located in five Grade II Listed townhouses in South Kensington. Home to some of the world’s most exciting rotating art exhibitors with a range in specialties.

name: Crystal Palace Bowl
description: Crystal Palace Bowl is a South London icon: A venue of legends from Pink Floyd to Bob Marley, with a Stirling Prize nominated sculptural stage, revived from ruin by a local community campaign and ready to host the next generation of talent!

name: Cut Glass Studio Ltd, Tottenham Hale
description: Unit used as an art studio in a small industrial estate.
address: 15-16 The High Cross Centre, Fountayne Road

name: Devonport Mausoleum
description: Beautiful mausoleum in former Royal Navy cemetery, restored 1999 by the University of Greenwich. Many interesting plaques and grave stones.

name: Dorich House Museum
description: The former studio home of the sculptor Dora Gordine and her husband the Hon. Richard Hare, a scholar of Russian art and literature. 1930s house over four floors including a flat roof terrace and views of Richmond Park.
address: Dorich House Museum, 67 Kingston Vale, SW15 3RN

name: Eastbury Manor House
description: Architecturally distinguished and well-preserved, brick-built, Elizabethan Grade I listed manor house. Contains 17C wall-paintings, wood panelling, a charming walled garden and a fine Tudor turret. Many original features have been restored.
address: Eastbury Manor House, Eastbury Square, Barking

name: Emery Walker's House
description: The home of Emery Walker, printer, antiquary and mentor to William Morris. A unique Arts and Crafts domestic interior.

name: Fitzrovia Chapel
description: Loughborough Pearson's red brick building is unimposing from the outside, but inside is a riot of Gothic Revival design. Golden mosaics reveal the character of the Grade II* listed chapel, built as part of the Middlesex Hospital.

name: Frederick W Paine Funeral Directors
description: The town's oldest firm of funeral directors has conducted funerals from these premises since 1908. The original interior is Grade II listed. The building also contains the Frederick W Paine Museum and the firm's archive.
address: 24 Old London Road, Kingston upon Thames

name: Fulham Palace
description: Early Tudor Palace with Georgian reception rooms, Victorian Chapel, 13 acres of botanic gardens and walled garden.

name: GARDEN OF EARTHLY DELIGHTS🌱🐝🍅🦋
description: The Garden of Earthly Delights is a community garden and a "meanwhile" space to raise awareness of empty spaces in the city, grow food for the local community and increase biodiversity. We hold workshops and events to which all are welcome.

name: Garrick's Temple to Shakespeare, Hampton
description: Grade I listed Georgian garden building. Tribute to Shakespeare built in the Ionic style by actor David Garrick. Arcadian Thames-side setting in restored 18C gardens thought to be by Capability Brown.
address: Garrick's Lawn, Hampton Court Road, , Hampton

name: Golders Green Quaker Meeting House
description: Delightful brick and tile building inspired by the famous 1688 Meeting House at Jordans in Buckinghamshire. A simple building in a tranquil setting, reflecting the Quakers' beliefs.

name: Gustafson Porter + Bowman
description: The building was designed by the internationally acclaimed architects David Chipperfield Architects and is now occupied by Gustafson Porter + Bowman. The areas are arranged spaciously with an abundance of natural light throughout.

name: Hampstead Friends Meeting House
description:
Listed Arts and Crafts freestyle building with plain interior and many charming original features, sympathetically modernised in 1991. Entrance via listed gateway.
NOTE Please wear facemasks.

name: Hampstead Garden Suburb Artisans' Quarter Walk
description: Guided walks of 'the most nearly perfect example of the 20C Garden Suburb' (Pevsner), designed by Unwin & Parker, Lutyens, Bunney, Baillie Scott and others. Informally laid out terraces and picturesque Arts and Crafts vernacular cottages.

name: Hedge Lane
description: Remodelling and extension of rear of house to make a kitchen/diner/lounge with ancillary wc and utility spaces and a new small urban garden.

name: Hermitage Community Moorings
description: A development of residential and recreational moorings for historic vessels on the Thames. The unique Pier House, built to a high specification, provides a floating community centre just downstream from Tower Bridge.

name: Holy Trinity Church Sloane Square
description: A sumptuous feast of Victorian stained glass & bold sacred sculpture in what Sir John Betjeman called the 'cathedral of the Arts and Crafts movement.' Work by William Morris, Edward Burne-Jones, William Blake Richamind & Christopher Whall.

name: Homework Open Studio (A4)
description: Visit our studio in David Kohn Architects' building A4 in Design District and see where we formulate and manufacture all of our products. Sample our full range and take part in a perfume oil making workshop.

name: House Mill
description: The World’s largest tidal mill. 5-storey, timber-framed, brick-clad timber watermill with four waterwheels, originally built 1776 to mill grain for distillery trade. Operational until 1940. On historic 3 Mills Site, Clock Mill adjacent.
address: Three Mill Lane, Bromley by Bow , E3 3DU

name: Hoxton Docks
description: Antepavilion Commission offers emerging architects and makers opportunities to create new work through hands-on construction. Works are put on temporary display in Columbia/ Brunswick Wharf, situated on the Regents Canal in Haggerston.

name: Ingrebourne Valley Visitor Centre
description: Ingrebourne Valley Visitor Centre, at Hornchurch Country Park, the Former RAF Hornchurch Airfield.

name: Institut français du Royaume-Uni
description: 1939 Art Deco Grade II listed building refurbished in 1950, then restructured and modernised in 2014. Contains an authentically classic cinema, private salons and multimedia library.

name: Isokon Building (Lawn Road Flats)
description: Grade I listed 1934 residential block of flats in Hampstead, designed by the Canadian modernist architect Wells Coates for clients Jack and Molly Pritchard. English Heritage blue plaque for Bauhaus masters Gropius, Breuer and Moholy-Nagy.

name: Jonathan Tuckey Design Studio
description: This transformation of a derelict pub into an architecture studio doubles up as a gallery and lecture theatre. The new office is an example of the practice’s approach towards existing structures and intelligent architectural interventions.

name: Kaymet Factory
description: The operational factory of Kaymet, a maker of trays and trolleys since 1947. A hidden 1950s building with a small yard, originally a printing works. It is brick built, with clear-storey glazing and tubular truss north-light main shed roof.

name: Ladywell Self Build Community Hub
description: This flexible community space was constructed by self-build volunteers in 2019, making use of reclaimed materials. It offers a window onto the RUSS building site where 36 affordable, sustainable homes are being built for completion in 2023.

name: Lambeth Town Hall
description: Landmark Edwardian Baroque style town hall  in red brick and Portland stone landmark tower.  Interior has marble staircase and ornate council chamber.  Atrium, reception and courtyard spaces created in 2018. Grade II listed.

name: Lincoln's Inn
description: Lincoln’s Inn has been an association of barristers for over 600 years. An 11-acre site combining gardens with mediaeval, Victorian, Georgian, and modern buildings, including banqueting halls, a law library, a chapel, and teaching space.
address: The Honourable Society of Lincoln's Inn

name: LivingFunky House
description: Wates Built 1960s Semi, extended & renovated into a vibrant, colourful stylish 21st Century home. Embracing Midcentury & Modern design with Bold Colours, Patterns & Materials to create the feeling of space, light & individuality throughout.

name: Local discoveries: Street Art in Brixton – a virtual tour with a London Blue Badge Tourist Guide
description: Street Art and Murals can be found in many places across London. They are artistic expressions that can be challenging, thought provoking, funny or beautiful. We will explore the area of Brixton and see the art that celebrates a community.

name: Markfield Beam Engine and House
description:
A masterpiece of Victorian engineering, Markfield Beam Engine provided a vital public health facility from 1855-1964. 

On 17 & 18 Sept the 1888 beam engine will be steaming as follows:
12.30 - 1.15pm 
2.00 - 2.45pm 
3.30 - 4.15pm
address: Markfield Park, Markfield Road, South Tottenham

name: Migration Museum
description: The Migration Museum is located inside the Lewisham Shopping Centre.

name: Mount Pleasant
description: A former Victorian workhouse that has been transformed through LB Camden's Community Investment Programme into a state of the art facility for 50 homeless people laid out around a beautiful suntrap courtyard.

name: Mountain View House
description: A radical transformation of an Edwardian Semi that has been completely opened up and renovated with bold materials and bright colours. A stage-set mountain is elevated on an exposed structure to form the striking rear extension.

name: Museum of Neoliberalism
description: The museum is situated in a shopfront in Leegate Shopping Centre, which has been described by the Evening Standard as "the worst shopping precinct in the country."

name: New Ground (online only)
description: 25 homes designed with the Older Women’s Co-Housing group using PTE’s ‘fabric first’ approach which maximises the benefits of orientation, air-tightness, insulation and following the co-housing model. www.youtube.com/watch?v=9q25nbEl8rg

name: New London Architecture
description: Visit New London Architecture's pop-up gallery at Westfield Stratford City to see the largest model of London. Celebrate the 10-year anniversary of the Games and learn more about the past and future of Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park.
address: The Street , Westfield Stratford City , E20 1EN

name: Nunhead Cemetery
description: Magnificent Victorian cemetery with Gothic chapel & restored & ruined lodge. One of London's wildest cemeteries. Part restored with the help of a lottery grant. 52 acres of woodland, with bats, owls, foxes & squirrels. Grade II*  landscape.

name: Old Royal Naval College
description: Sir Christopher Wren's riverside masterpiece in Greenwich, built as the Royal Hospital for Seamen and begun in 1696.
address: Old Royal Naval College, Greenwich, SE10 9NN

name: Old Royal Naval College - King William Court
description: Wren-designed building completed under the direction of Hawksmoor and Vanbrugh, 1698-1712. Original wood panelling, refurbished by Dannatt Johnson in 2001 for University of Greenwich.
address: King William Court, 30 Park Row, SE10 9NN

name: Old Royal Naval College - Queen Anne Court
description: Wren and Hawksmoor building, completed 1749 when Thomas Ripley built the pavilions facing the river. Highlights include council boardroom, grand staircase and restored Portland stonework. Refurbished in 2000 for University of Greenwich.
address: Queen Anne Court , 30 Park Row, SE10 9NN

name: Old Royal Naval College - Queen Mary Court
description: Last major building on the site (1751). Original layout, timber panelling, barrel vaulting and Portland stone. Refurbished in 2000 by Dannatt Johnson for University of Greenwich.
address: Queen Mary Court, 30 Park Row, SE10 9NN

name: OmVed Gardens Chelsea Flower Show Pavilion
description: A pavilion inspired by the organic shapes of nature and the transformational potential of seeds, currently hosting the exhibition "Saving Seed". The walls can rotate position allowing the space to perform like a seed cracking open.

name: Open Bookshop at 1 Finsbury Avenue
description: Celebrate the best writing about architects and the city at AHMM’s pop-up bookshop at Morag Myerscough’s Atoll. We’ve curated a special collection of books and maps by established publishers, smaller independents and Open City itself.

name: People's Museum Somers Town
description:
A great little museum set in the Grade 2 listed Ossulston Estate - a prime example of pre-war Social housing - based on Karl Marz Hof in Vienna.
Open Wednesdays to Saturdays throughout Festival 
Sunday 11th Event

name: Quaker Meeting House, Wanstead
description: Four hexagon Modernist building within an Epping Forest setting. A sunny meeting room for Quaker worship faces a wooded burial ground of simple headstones, including those of Elizabeth Fry, William Mead, Guilielma Lister and Norman Frith.

name: Queen Elizabeth's Hunting Lodge
description: Tudor timber-framed hunt standing/grandstand (1543),  Henry VIII Tudor food display. Gateway to 6,000 acres ancient Epping Forest, once royal hunting ground, protected since 1878 by City of London, Grade II*.  Epping Forest visitor Centre.

name: Quentin Blake Centre for Illustration - New River Head
description:
An industrial heritage site that was the hub of one of London’s first major pieces of urban infrastructure.
Its 18th and 19th century buildings will be restored by Tim Ronalds Architects to create the Quentin Blake Centre for Illustration.

name: RSA (Royal Society for the encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce)
description: A very good example of Georgian/Adam architecture. Restoration 2012 of Great Room (James Barry paintings), Benjamin Franklin room. 2019, restoration and installation of 1754-2018 mural in the new Long Gallery.

name: Roca London Gallery
description: Designed by the world renowned Zaha Hadid Architects, Roca London Gallery is a unique space where water acts as the architectural theme. Guests can also visit 'Everything Flows', a major exhibition exploring the work of Zaha Hadid Design.

name: Rolling Bridge
description: A revolutionary first-of-its-kind opening bridge. Powered by nothing but hand winches, this 12 tonne weathering steel and oak structure playfully rolls and inverts to allow boats to pass from river to dock.

name: Rudolf Steiner House
description: Unique example of Expressionist architecture in London with sculptural staircase based on organic plant forms. Grade II listed. New cafe area and renovations in 2008. Refurbishment of theatre and foyer 2020.

name: Saddlers' Hall
description: Home of the Worshipful Company of Saddlers, Saddlers’ Hall is built in a neo-classical style and impresses with bespoke period furniture, historical antiquities, and paintings. The highlight is the Great Hall.

name: Sands End Arts & Community Centre
description: Amongst the RIBA Stirling Prize shortlist 2022 sits Mæ Architect's Sands End Arts & Community scheme in Fulham. The centre consists of a single-storey building comprising bright, airy and flexible event spaces and a community café.

name: Self-guided Tower Gardens Garden Suburb Walk
description: One of the first garden suburbs in the world, 2-storey terraced cottages retaining decorative architectural features. LCC created 'housing of the working classes' role for architects' department under Riley, member of the Art Workers guild.
address: 5 Tower Gardens Road, North Tottenham, N17 7PX

name: Shoreditch Town Hall
description: Once one of the grandest civic buildings in London and now a great arts venue, the Grade II listed Shoreditch Town Hall boasts many spaces, from the Victorian grandeur of the Assembly Hall to the intimate warren of untouched basement rooms.
address: Shoreditch Town Hall, 380 Old Street, EC1V 9LT

name: Shrewsbury House
description: Built in 1923, to replace its 18C namesake, Grade ll listed Shrewsbury House is the focus of the Shrewsbury Park Estate conservation area, built 1934-1936 by John Laing and Sons. Two Civil Defence centres are within the grounds.

name: Small Beer Brewery
description: The Small Beer Brewery was founded in 2017 by James Grundy and  Felix James. It is the first of its kind, specialising in brewing world class beer at a sociable strength.

name: South London Theatre
description: Grade II listed 1881 former fire station with prominent watch tower and original fire doors.
address: The Old Fire Station, 2a Norwood High Street

name: Springbank
description: One of a pair of modern houses on a sensitive site in a conservation area. A triple-height staircase atrium brings light into the heart of the house and ground floor areas open onto courtyard gardens on three sides.

name: St Andrew's Kingsbury (new church)
description: Meticulous 1930s rebuilding (complete with original furnishings) of an 1840s Marylebone church. Grade I listed. Contains works by Pugin, Burges, Street, Pearson and Butterfield.
address: junction of Church Lane/Tudor Gardens/ Old Chur

name: St Augustine's Tower
description: Grade I listed, remaining tower of medieval parish church, with working late 16C clock. New exhibition of Hackney's history. Extensive views from roof. (Organised by Hackney Historic Buildings Trust).

name: St Barnabas' Church and Mission Hall
description: Early 20th C Grade II* listed church designed by CH Reilly. Byzantine in structure but prefiguring Modernism in its aesthetic, Nairn judged it “the best church of its date in London”, Reilly “the building I should like to be remembered by”.
address: St Barnabas' Church, Shackewell Row, E8 2EA

name: St Bride's Church, Fleet Street
description: Wren designed building of 1675, interior lost in blitz of 1940, reopened 1957 with 'Wren inspired' interior
address: St Bride's Church, St Bride's Avenue, EC4Y 8AU

name: St Dunstan and All Saints Church
description: Grade I listed early medieval parish church (from 952 before Tower of London) in spacious churchyard. Fine interior: Anglo-Saxon Rood, Norman font, 'squint', fine memorials incl founders of Trinity House, 1950s glass. Bells of Stepney.

name: St Giles’ Cripplegate
description: A rare surviving medieval church in The City of London. 2nd bomb of the Blitz hit it. Poet John Milton buried beneath the chancel step. Early Jewish graveyard. Beside the old London Wall. Shakespeare, Bunyan, Blake & Defoe all feature.

name: St John the Baptist Holland Road
description:
Possibly the last stone-vaulted building built in London – of soaring nobility embellished with carvings and fittings of exceptional quality.
Recently cleaned and restored by Opus Conservation, Humphries & Jones and others

name: St Jude on the Hill
description: Eccentric Edwardian church, Grade I listed. Described by Simon Jenkins as 'one of Lutyens' most distinctive creations'. Extensive 20C wall-paintings by Walter Starmer, memorial to horses of WWI. Local archives display.

name: St Lawrence Church, Morden
description: Grade I listed Norman brick-built church consisting of a nave and chancel. Tower at the west end. Gothic-style stone windows from the old church inserted into the present 1636 structure. Rare 17th Century glass was restored in 2020.

name: St Margaret's Church, Lee
description:
The Church was built in 1839/41 as a white 'Hall-Church'. 
The 1870s Gothic Revivalism was overseen to a very high standard, by James Brooks and helped by 10 top craftsmen of the day. We also have a WWI Memorial by Violet Pinwill.
address: St Margarets Church,  Lee Terrace, SE13 5DN

name: St Mary the Virgin
description: Small Grade I listed 12C chapel in lovely churchyard setting, it retains original architectural features and has interesting brasses, monuments and stained glass windows.
address: Church Road, Manor Park, Little Ilford, E12 6HA

name: St Mary's Church Bromley
description:
A plain Victorian Church set in a wooded Churchyard, with a vibrant and striking set of Murals around the altar and the Choir. 
Has indoor toilet facilities. 
A good quality well used organ in good condition, and an excellent accoustic
address: St Mary's Church, College Road, Bromley

name: St Mary's Church, Battersea
description: Classic Grade I listed Georgian church with outstanding interior and monuments. Renovated 2019/20.

name: St Michael and All Angels Church
description: James Maltby Bignall (1827-1885) worked in the practice of Sir George Gilbert Scott, the architect of St Pancras Station. The style of St Michael's is late Gothic Revival, in its size and height reminiscent of Northern European churches.

name: St Nicholas Church, Chislehurst
description: Medieval Parish Church, 15C, enlarged & rebuilt in 19C. Shingle spire 1857, by Wollaston. Chancel by Ferrey, lengthened with East wall by Bodley & Garner. Scadbury Chapel (Walsingham tombs), with rood screen. Clock by Dent, 1858.

name: St Pancras Chambers and Clock Tower
description: Former Midland Grand Hotel, now St Pancras Renaissance Hotel and Chambers apartments. Includes hotel lobby and clock tower.
address: The Forecourt, St Pancras Station, Euston Road

name: St Pancras Church & Crypt
description: The church (1822 - Grade I listed) is an early and important example of Greek Revival architecture in London. Significant features include the caryatids and tower copied from the Acropolis and the atmospheric crypt.
address: Euston Road/Upper Woburn Place NW1, NW1 2BA

name: St Peter & St Paul Harlington
description: Grade I listed church dating from 1086, representing the architectural styles of many centuries, including Norman font and carved cats heads around Norman south doorway arch, Easter sepulchre and ancient yew tree in churchyard.
address: St Peter's Way, High Street, Harlington

name: St. Mary's Church, Walthamstow Village
description: Grade II* listed church dating from 12C with Medieval, Tudor, Georgian & Victorian features. 16C Tower. Church refurbishment and new extension in progress in 2022. Over 1300 monuments with four Grade II listed tombs in churchyard.
address: Church End (top of Church Hill), Walthamstow

name: Stamford brook walk
description: Start Stamford Brook tube. Follow the hidden river, Stamford Brook, through streets and parks.  Amongst the architecture we will see on this route is a delightful square with great variety   Finish near Hammersmith Station around 4 pm

name: Stanley Arts
description: A public hall, theatre and gallery in grand Edwardian style. Grade II listed, Stanley made fun of the Victorian style with grand ornamentation. It reflects Stanley's interest in science, the arts and public cultural improvement.

name: Stockwell Bus Garage
description: Ground breaking post-war reinforced concrete building with cavernous interior. Sweeping roof structure with a clear single span of 194 feet, the lack of internal columns making best use of space. Opening by kind permission of Go-Ahead.
address: Binfield Road main entrance (meet by garage sig

name: Sukkat Shalom Reform Synagogue
description: Grade II* listed, originally the Merchant Seaman's Orphan Asylum, bought by the synagogue in 1995 and restored with Lottery Fund grant. Timber work and windows from a synagogue which was inside the Tottenham Home for Incurables.

name: Suleymaniye Mosque
description: 6-storey building featuring a Western exterior and traditional Islamic interior, modelled on the Blue Mosque in Istanbul. Has dome and minaret tower.

name: T J Boulting
description: Red brick and Portland stone corner building with three prominent signs in Arts & Craft style lettering in green and gold mosaic for the company 'TJ Boulting & Sons'.

name: Table Top Museums at the Art Workers' Guild
description: 1713 terraced house with 1914 hall at rear. Notable renovated Arts and Crafts interior. Newly refurbished glass vaulted courtyard. Portraits of Guild Masters since 1884.

name: Temple Bar
description: Temple Bar is a 350 year old gateway to the City of London, designed by Sir Christopher Wren. It formerly stood in Fleet Street, and was the last surviving gateway to the City of London.

name: The Boleyn Tavern
description: The Boleyn is a prominent landmark at a crossroads right by the former West Ham football ground. It is an exuberant piece of French-style Renaissance architecture built in 1899-1900 and reopened in June 2021 after a spectacular restoration.
address: 1 Barking Road, The Boleyn Tavern, E6 1PW

name: The Brunel Museum
description: London's story of an engineering family that changed the world. Dramatic new staircase below sculpture garden leads to underground chamber. Travel by train through first underwater shopping arcade & fairground to view Thames Tunnel portico.

name: The Church of Our Most Holy Redeemer
description: A unique II* listed Italianate church by John Dando Sedding with attached Campanile and Institute Building. Of particular significance in the church is the imposing baldacchino over the High Altar, which dominates the east end.

name: The City Churches: St Stephen Walbrook
description: Wren's own and 'finest City Church'.  Fantastic architecture with different shapes,  twelve Corinthian columns and covered by huge dome - first of its type. Central stone altar by Henry Moore installed in 1987. Birthplace of the Samaritans.

name: The Family Kitchen, Royal Botanic Gardens Kew
description: The Family Kitchen & Shop, Royal Botanic Gardens Kew, designed by architects HOK with front of house interiors by Mizzi Studio and Lumsden Design, is an environmentally driven, education-led food space for visitors of all ages.
address: Royal Botanic Gardens,   , Kew Rd, TW9 3AB

name: The Foundry
description: Tucked behind a busy road in W12, this former foundry is a multi-level development featuring an architects’ studio with courtyards and spaces for exhibitions and musical performances. The  building's 15m brick chimney is a local landmark.

name: The Horseshoe Bend Kiosk, St James's Park, Near Buckingham Palace
description: Part of a public realm enhancement project across London’s Royal Parks from 2017 to 2021, architecture and design practice Mizzi Studio saw the installation of a brass tubular food kiosk in St James' Park at the foot of Buckingham Palace.
address: The Horseshoe Kiosk, St James' Park

name: The Old Deanery
description: This Grade I Mansion House, close to St Paul's Cathedral was designed by Edward Woodroofe in 1669 and completed in 1673.  The residence of successive Deans of St Pauls until the 1970's today it is the office to the Bishop of London
address: The Old Deanery, Deans Court, EC4V 5AA

name: The Old Schoolhouse
description: Originally St, Mary's Infants School, later as Holy Innocents' National School until 1934. It then became derelict until 1981 when it became headquarters of the Hornsey Historical Society in 1981 after refurbishment.

name: The Perimeter
description: An interlocking set of gallery spaces and archive across 5 floors of an old 3-storey 19C warehouse in a mews street in Bloomsbury. Its dark brick concealing a newly luminous interior carved out inside.

name: The Photography Foundation Open House (D2)
description:
Come and see our light filled space, green exterior and find out more about what we do at The Photography Foundation! 

Browse our mini exhibition & zines, and have your photo taken in our pop-up studio by one of our alumni.

name: The Place
description:
Grade II listed building from 1889 with diverse historical functions - now functioning as Theatre venue and dance studios.
A more recent remodelling and additional dance studios has made the complex a bright and contemporary venue.

name: The Post Building
description:
London is known for its rooftops. The Roof Garden at The Post Building has been designed as a one-off location for enjoyment, work and wellness looking out over some of its most memorable.

Open to the public 7 days a week!

name: The Priory, Orpington
description: Grade II listed building dating back to 1270. Following the dissolution of Christ Church Priory in Orpington in the 1530s, the house became a rectory. Additions were built in 1959 to put in a library.

name: The Serpentine Coffee House, The Royal Parks, Opposite The Serpentine Gallery
description:
The Serpentine Coffee House overlooking the Serpentine Lake designed by Mizzi Studio, with its undulating brass canopy roof that echoes a stingray’s flight through water,  has added a
new architectural landmark to London’s Hyde Park.
address: The Serpentine Coffee House, W Carriage Drive

name: The Wiener Library
description: Sensitive yet bold refurbishment of historic Grade II listed townhouse for The Wiener Library including dramatic first floor reading room, mezzanine and ground floor exhibition spaces.

name: Thornhill Square
description: A tour of one of the largest and best preserved early Victorian squares and gardens in London, also with a magnificent and original public library of 1906, which shows Byzantine and Art Nouveau influences, and a remarkable Gothic church.
address: Meet outside the main door of St Andrew’s Churc

name: Tooting Bec Lido
description: Outdoor pool 100x33 yards. One million gallons of unheated water. Iconic outdoor cubicle doors, fountain and café added in the 1930s, with Art Deco style entrance in 2001. Sports hall pavilion added in 2016.
address: Tooting Bec Lido, Tooting Bec Road, SW16 1RU

name: Tower and Churchyard of St Mary's Hornsey
description: Grade II* listed tower with restored chapel remaining from Medieval parish church. Tour includes crypt, ringing chamber & main roof with excellent extensive views in all directions. Organised by Friends of Hornsey Church Tower.

name: Turning Earth Ceramics Haringey - N22
description: The new ceramics studio occupies the top floor of a beautiful old saw-toothed factory building within the Crawley Road industrial estate, one of several new creative businesses joining the area

name: Turning Earth Ceramics Highgate - N6
description: Former indoor garden design workshop converted into a open-access ceramics studio.

name: Turning Earth Ceramics Hoxton - E2
description: Two railway arches have been repurposed into a ceramic studio.

name: Turning Earth Ceramics Leyton - E10
description: Ceramics centre for the Lee Valley, covering the entire top floor of an old hardware factory. Three rooms, providing just over 8000 sq ft of floor space; the main room is capped by its original saw-tooth glass roof feature.

name: Two Temple Place
description: Completed in 1895, Two Temple Place is a dazzling neo-Gothic gem on the Victoria Embankment, designed by gothic revivalist architect, John Loughborough Pearson, & commissioned by & built for William Waldorf Astor, as his estate office.

name: Two-up Two-down House
description: Two-Up Two-Down House is a reworking of a Victorian mid terrace by architects Khan Bonshek. They use imaginative spatial devices to maximise the limited floor area. Double height volumes & blurring of rooms combine to create space & light.

name: UPDATED: City Information Centre
description: London's main tourist information centre is clad in a specially manufactured system of 220 pre-finished stainless steel panels. The subtly reflective surface provides a striking counterpoint to St Paul's. NOTE: Closed on Monday 19 September

name: UPDATED: Guildhall Art Gallery
description:
UPDATED: Open daily 10.30am-4pm. Closed Mon 19 September.
Guided tours 12.15pm & 1.15pm on Tuesdays, Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays & Sundays, see below.
Home of the City of London's art collection, & remains of London's Roman Amphitheatre

name: UPDATED: London's Roman Amphitheatre
description:
UPDATED: Open daily 10.30am-4pm Closed Mon 19 September.
Combined guided tours of Amphitheatre and Guildhall Art Gallery at 12.15pm & 1.15pm on Tuesdays, Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays & Sundays.
The capital’s only known Roman Amphitheatre
address: London’s Roman Amphitheatre at Guildhall Art Ga

name: Uncommon Projects
description: Uncommon Projects moved into their new showroom in June 2022. The showroom will be open for walk in visitors for the duration of Open House.

name: Union Chapel
description: A Grade I and II*  treasure that’s home to an inclusive church, an award winning venue, a unique organ and The Margins Project for those in crisis in London. Book organ workshop and performance https://unionchapel.org.uk/venue/whats-on

name: University of Greenwich, Stockwell Street
description: The building features a limestone exterior designed to 'complement but not mimic' the surrounding historical architecture, whilst behind the façade is a 4-storey composition of steel, glass and exposed concrete.

name: Valentines Mansion & Gardens
description: Large, late 17C Grade II* listed house with fine staircase and Venetian window and Georgian additions, used as a family dwelling until the early 1900s. Reopened to the public in Feb 2009 following extensive restoration works.

name: Vanbrugh Park Estate
description: Vanbrugh Park Estate was designed by Chamberlin, Powell and Bon. The estate shares many stylistic similarities with their wider work such as the semi-circular curved motifs, purposeful use of light, and approach to community living.
address: 18 Combe Avenue, Vanbrugh Park Estate, SE3 7PY

name: Walter Segal Self-build Houses
description: A close of 13 self-built houses. Each is unique, built using method developed by Walter Segal, who led the project in the 1980s. Houses have been extended and renovated. Sustainable features including solar electric, water & space heating.
address: Walters Way, Honor Oak Park , SE23 3LH

name: Walworth Garden
description: Our timber frame building was designed by Matrix Feminist Design Co-Operative, and built by women. It represents our community's history of activism-the same ethos that transformed our site from dereliction, into a thriving community garden

name: Wimbledon Windmill
description: Rare example of a hollow post mill (1817). Grade II* listed, it now contains a museum depicting the history and development of windmills in Britain. Many working models, windmill machinery, equipment and tools.

name: Wimbledon architecture walk
description: A 4-mile outdoor walking tour taking in a variety of Wimbledon's greater and lesser known buildings, led by Ramblers group, the Metropolitan Walkers. Includes Wimbledon Village, and several buildings new to the tour this year.

name: Winscombe Street 1960s terrace
description: Terrace of five three-storey houses and a studio incorporating a sequence of communal and private spaces. Influential prototype for Camden social housing developments of the 1960s and 70s.

name: Wizard Works Open Studio
description: Wizard Works, London's cutest adventure bike bag brand, will be opening their studio in North Greenwich's Design District for a behind the scenes look at all things bag making.
address: Unit 1 Building D2, 3 Dormer Yard, SE10 0EB

name: Woodfield Pavilion
description: A pre- 2nd WW - 1933 - now beautifully refurbished brick built sports pavilion surrounded by the fields of Tooting Common.
